content.card_other: A substance that can flow and takes shape of container. Includes liquids and gases. Cannot sustain shear stress - deforms continuously under tangential force.
Mass per unit volume. Scalar quantity. SI unit: kg/m³. For liquids, nearly constant with pressure. For gases, depends on temperature and pressure. Symbol: ρ (rho).
Force per unit area. Scalar quantity that acts in all directions equally in fluid at rest. SI unit: pascal (Pa) = N/m². In fluids, pressure transmitted equally in all directions (Pascal's law).
Pressure exerted by atmosphere due to weight of air above. Standard value: 1.013 × 10⁵ Pa = 1 atm = 760 mmHg = 101.3 kPa. Decreases with altitude.
Gauge pressure: Measured relative to atmospheric pressure. Absolute pressure: Total pressure including atmospheric. Absolute = Gauge + Atmospheric. Gauge can be negative (vacuum).
Pressure applied to enclosed fluid is transmitted undiminished to every point in fluid and to walls of container. Basis of hydraulic machines like hydraulic lift, brake systems.
Machine based on Pascal's law. Small force on small piston creates large force on large piston. Force ratio equals area ratio. Mechanical advantage = A₂/A₁.
A body immersed in fluid experiences upward buoyant force equal to weight of fluid displaced. Object floats if average density less than fluid, sinks if greater.
Upward force exerted by fluid on immersed object. Results from pressure difference between top and bottom of object. Explains why objects feel lighter in water.
For floating object in equilibrium: weight of object = weight of fluid displaced. Fraction submerged = (density of object)/(density of fluid). Ice floats because density less than water.

Internal friction in fluid that opposes relative motion between layers. Resistance to flow. SI unit: Pa·s or N·s/m². Symbol: η (eta). Honey has high viscosity, water has low. Decreases with temperature for liquids.
Smooth, orderly flow where fluid particles move in parallel layers without mixing. Velocity at any point remains constant in time. Occurs at low velocities. Characterized by smooth streamlines.
Irregular, chaotic flow with eddies and vortices. Velocity fluctuates randomly. Occurs at high velocities. Mixing between layers. Higher energy dissipation than laminar flow.
Theoretical fluid with zero viscosity (no internal friction) and incompressible (constant density). Does not exist in nature but good approximation for many liquids. Simplifies analysis.
For incompressible fluid in steady flow, product of cross-sectional area and velocity is constant along tube. Fluid moves faster through narrower sections. Mass conservation principle.
For ideal fluid in streamline flow, sum of pressure energy, kinetic energy per unit volume, and potential energy per unit volume remains constant. Pressure decreases where velocity increases.
Explains lift on airplane wing, Venturi meter, atomizer/sprayer, curve ball in sports, chimney functioning, blood flow in arteries.
Device to measure flow rate of fluid in pipe. Uses Bernoulli's principle - pressure drop in narrow section relates to flow velocity. Used in water supply, carburetors.
Speed of efflux (outflow) from opening in tank equals velocity acquired by object falling freely through same vertical distance. v = √(2gh). Special case of Bernoulli's equation.
Viscous drag force on sphere moving through fluid is proportional to radius, velocity, and viscosity. Valid for streamline flow around sphere at low velocities (small Reynolds number).
Maximum constant velocity attained by falling object when drag force equals weight. Net force becomes zero, no further acceleration. Depends on size, shape, density of object and viscosity of medium.
Dimensionless number predicting flow pattern. Low Re (< 2000): laminar flow. High Re (> 4000): turbulent flow. Intermediate: transitional. Re = ρvL/η where L is characteristic length.
